Biggest factor is whether humanitarian workers are able to get access to Boko Haram areas.  Boko Haram areas highly concord with areas of extreme food insecurity.  To extent famine is already present, humanitarian access would dramatically increase the probability of a famine being revealed and declared.  To extent famine is _not_ already present, humanitarian access may be able to prevent famine occurring.  Given humanitarian workers have not had access to these areas for at least 12 months, if I have to guess, lets give a 1 in 200 chance per week of humanitarian workers gaining access to Boko Haram areas _and_ discovering famine already existing _and_ triggering a UN declaration of famine.  0.995 ^ 16 weeks remaining = 92.5% probability that this _won't_ happen in 2017.  That sounds about right.

The practical effects are more or less the same; if you are displaced by Boko Haram and cannot farm your land you have nothing to live on, if a wide area is affected by Boko Haram less food is grown, if there is a shortage of food people starve. The Nigerian government seems to be ashamed of famine, but less ashamed of not being able to deal with Boko Haram. So it solicits aid to deal with Boko Haram and the consequences of Boko Haram, but  tries to avoid the famine declaration.

Famine looms in northeast Nigeria as food crisis worsens

In northern Nigeria, the improvement of the security situation continues to favor the return of displaced persons and refugees, but humanitarian aid remains insufficient due to limited funding. For example, many people in Borno, Yobe and Adamawa States remain in Crisis (IPC Phase 3) and Emergency (IPC Phase 4) food insecurity, with an increased risk of high levels of acute malnutrition and mortality. Less accessible areas, particularly in Borno State, experience similar or worse conditions and continue to face an elevated risk of Famine (IPC Phase 5) in 2017. 
Markets remain well stocked with local and imported food, helping to meet rising demand during the lean season. However, food prices are rising seasonally as household stocks decline and households become more market dependent. These increases are more pronounced in the eastern basin, particularly in the Lake Chas Basin where market flows remain disrupted by civil insecurity, and in Nigeria where the depreciation of the Naira enables the rise of prices in the areas in conflict. What is a famine in substantial terms?
See the five scale system of FEWSNET to 'measure' a threat or famine or acutal famine (https://www.fews.net).
	 
What is a famine in UN terms?
Certain measures of mortality, malnutrition and hunger must be met. The criteria are:
· At least 20% of households in an area face extreme food shortages with a limited ability to cope
· The prevalence of acute malnutrition in children exceeds 30%
· The death rate exceeds two persons per 10,000 persons per day

Which actors are at work in the process of declaring a famine?
· players usually are 
(1) the government of the affected country, 
(2) various agencies of the United Nations and a 
(3) "Famine Early Warning Systems Network" — called FEWSNET for short — that the U.S. government set up in the mid-1980s to collect and analyze data from a range of sources. FEWSNET draws from both survey data collected on the ground by aid agencies and governments as well as climate and satellite data provided by U.S. agencies like NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

Pro

Con

· The first two points point to Nigeria's reputation and influence… I am not sure about the preferences of Nigerias Gov since it could also help Nigeria to have a famine declaration by the UN (resources, help, media coverage concerning a problem they cannot handle due to their failing and failed states characteristics; and democratic norm may not hinder the declaration of a humanitarian catastrophe); I am also not sure whether they have so much influence to prevent a declaration.

· The points on FEWSNET are striking, however.
· The last point on the UN is a little overdrawn. However, it could well be that the UN is trying to avoid a noisy declaration, i.e. that is not valid - as I pointed out above.
	 
All in all: it is a very hard question. Given the momentum of the situation to become worse and worse, the chances are above the 50 percent threshold. But it is far from certain. My guess is that we are around 66 to 80 percent.
The most serious problem is that we seem to know very little on how the decision processes on famine declaration are organized and which stakeholders do a power play, which preferences they have, how much salience these preference have to them and how much influence they can have… 
Also we lack the understanding of the dynamics of famine crisis, e.g.: How likely is it that a famine can be prevented once it was diagnosed as (very) likely to happen and thereby mobilizing international help to prevent it?
